articles.title: Scientists in Japan create a new wine grape with a wild twist
articles.summary: Okayama scientists have crafted a new wine grape, Muscat Shiragai, merging the wild Shiraga and Muscat of Alexandria. The variety is part of a larger collaboration between academia, industry, and local government to boost regional identity through wine. Early tastings revealed a sweet, smooth flavor, and wider cultivation is planned.
articles.content:
A research team led by Professor Emeritus Takuji Hoshino of Okayama University of Science (OUS) has successfully cultivated a new wine grape variety called "Muscat Shiragai." The hybrid was produced by crossing the wild Shiraga grape, a species native only to the Takahashi River basin in Okayama Prefecture, with Muscat of Alexandria. The group has already submitted the new variety for registration with Japan's Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF), and the application has been formally accepted.

At a press event hosted by OUS, Professor Hoshino shared his vision: "I wanted to create a wine grape that incorporates wild genetic traits. If this grape becomes widely cultivated and its wine contributes to regional revitalization and tourism, that would be the best outcome."

Inspiration From a Rare Wild Grape

Professor Hoshino, an expert in plant systematics, founded the Institute of Viticulture and Enology at OUS in April 2017. During his collaboration with Funao Winery in Kurashiki City, he became interested in the Shiraga grape, a rare and endangered wild species found only in specific parts of Okayama Prefecture. This discovery sparked the idea of developing an original, locally bred wine grape by combining Shiraga with Muscat of Alexandria.

To bring the idea to life, OUS signed a comprehensive partnership agreement in February 2018 with Kurashiki City and Funao Winery. The collaboration became part of a national initiative focused on regional revitalization and the "branding of local resources," positioning the project as both a scientific and cultural effort.

By fiscal year 2022, the team had produced wines from several experimental breeding lines. Each was tested for sugar levels, acidity, pH, and overall taste. After years of refinement, the most promising strain was chosen, and "Muscat Shiragai" was officially established as a new variety in 2024.

The registration application was jointly submitted by Kake Educational Institution and Kurashiki City in December 2024 and was made public in June 2025. Full approval and registration are expected to be completed within the next four to five years.

A Warm Reception at the Press Conference

The press conference included key representatives such as Kurashiki Deputy Mayor Kenji Komatsu, Funao Winery CEO Kenichiro Miyake, and OUS President Hiroyuki Hirano. Attendees sampled both the Muscat Shiragai grapes and the wine made from them. The fruit was described as "sweet and very delicious," while the wine impressed tasters with its "subtle Muscat aroma and smooth drinking quality."

Deputy Mayor Komatsu expressed optimism: "We are very much looking forward to offering a wine filled with the unique charm that can only be produced in Kurashiki. We also anticipate further research results to refine Muscat Shiragai into an even more sophisticated grape."

CEO Miyake added: "With Muscat Shiragai as a branded grape, we hope to create a new high-value red wine identified with Kurashiki as its place of origin. Please look forward to the day when we can bring this to market."

President Hirano noted: "Collaboration among industry, academia, and government is essential for building innovative local communities. OUS will continue integrating education and research, returning the results to the community, and contributing to solving regional and social issues."

At present, 20 Muscat Shiragai vines are being cultivated at both Funao Winery and the OUS vineyard, producing 41.6 kilograms of grapes in 2024. In addition, 300 grafted vines were planted at the end of fiscal year 2023. The goal is to harvest more than 500 kilograms by 2028-2029. The research team is also refining vineyard management techniques, such as leaf removal, fertilization, and irrigation, to further enhance grape quality.

The Legacy of the Shiraga Grape

The Shiraga grape was first identified as a new species in 1918 by renowned botanist Tomitaro Makino. Its Japanese name honors Jukichi Shiraga, a botanist from Niimi City who discovered the plant. This wild grape is known for its naturally high sugar content, low acidity, and resistance to fruit cracking, as well as its tolerance to diseases such as black rot and ripe rot.

articles.personality_title: Japanese scientists create new wine grape blending wild and cultivated traits
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**  
Scientists in Okayama, Japan, have been working to develop new wine grapes that reflect the unique local environment. They focused on combining wild grapes native to the region with popular cultivated types to create something new and special.

**What happened**  
A team led by Professor Emeritus Takuji Hoshino at Okayama University of Science created a new grape variety called Muscat Shiragai. This grape is a hybrid of the wild Shiraga grape, found only near the Takahashi River in Okayama, and the Muscat of Alexandria grape. The new grape was officially submitted for registration with Japan’s Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries and accepted for review. The scientists worked with Kurashiki City and Funao Winery, tasting and testing grapes and wine from several breeding lines before choosing the best one.

**Impact**  
Muscat Shiragai combines special traits from the wild grape, like high sugar and disease resistance, with the smooth flavor of Muscat grapes. Early tastings described the grape as sweet and the wine as smooth with a subtle Muscat aroma. This new grape is important because it can help boost local pride, tourism, and the economy by creating a wine unique to Okayama. It also helps protect the rare wild Shiraga grape by using its genetics in a new way.

**What's next step**  
Currently, 20 vines are growing at the university and winery, with plans to expand to 300 vines. The team aims to harvest over 500 kilograms of grapes by 2028-2029. They are also improving how they care for the vines to make better grapes. Full approval for the grape variety is expected within the next four to five years, after which the wine could be widely produced and sold.

**One-sentence takeaway**  
Scientists in Okayama have created a new wine grape that blends rare wild genetics with cultivated flavors, aiming to enrich local culture and economy through unique, high-quality wine.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques japonais créent un nouveau cépage de vin mêlant traits sauvages et cultivés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**  
Des scientifiques d'Okayama, au Japon, travaillent à développer de nouveaux cépages qui reflètent l’environnement local unique. Ils ont cherché à combiner des raisins sauvages natifs de la région avec des variétés cultivées populaires pour créer quelque chose de nouveau et spécial.

**Ce qui s'est passé**  
Une équipe dirigée par le professeur émérite Takuji Hoshino de l’Université des sciences d’Okayama a créé un nouveau cépage appelé Muscat Shiragai. Ce raisin est un hybride entre le raisin sauvage Shiraga, que l'on trouve seulement près de la rivière Takahashi à Okayama, et le Muscat d'Alexandrie. Le nouveau cépage a été officiellement soumis pour enregistrement au Ministère japonais de l’agriculture et accepté pour examen. Les scientifiques ont travaillé avec la ville de Kurashiki et la cave Funao, goûtant et testant plusieurs lignées avant de choisir la meilleure.

**Impact**  
Le Muscat Shiragai combine des traits spéciaux du raisin sauvage, comme un taux de sucre élevé et une résistance aux maladies, avec la douceur des saveurs du Muscat. Les premières dégustations ont décrit le raisin comme sucré et le vin comme doux avec un arôme subtil de Muscat. Ce nouveau cépage est important car il peut renforcer la fierté locale, le tourisme et l’économie en créant un vin unique à Okayama. Il contribue aussi à protéger le rare raisin sauvage Shiraga en utilisant ses gènes d’une nouvelle manière.

**Prochaine étape**  
Actuellement, 20 plants poussent à l’université et à la cave, avec un projet d’extension à 300 plants. L’équipe vise à récolter plus de 500 kilogrammes de raisins d’ici 2028-2029. Ils améliorent aussi les techniques de culture pour produire de meilleurs raisins. L’approbation complète du cépage est attendue dans les quatre à cinq prochaines années, après quoi le vin pourra être produit et vendu à grande échelle.

**Résumé en une phrase**  
Des scientifiques d’Okayama ont créé un nouveau cépage qui mêle des gènes sauvages rares à des saveurs cultivées, avec pour but d’enrichir la culture locale et l’économie grâce à un vin unique et de qualité.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos japoneses crean una nueva uva para vino que mezcla rasgos silvestres y cultivados
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**  
Científicos en Okayama, Japón, han estado trabajando para desarrollar nuevas uvas para vino que reflejen el entorno local único. Se enfocaron en combinar uvas silvestres nativas de la región con tipos cultivados populares para crear algo nuevo y especial.

**Qué pasó**  
Un equipo dirigido por el profesor emérito Takuji Hoshino de la Universidad de Ciencias de Okayama creó una nueva variedad de uva llamada Muscat Shiragai. Esta uva es un híbrido de la uva silvestre Shiraga, que solo se encuentra cerca del río Takahashi en Okayama, y la uva Muscat de Alejandría. La nueva uva fue oficialmente presentada para su registro ante el Ministerio de Agricultura, Silvicultura y Pesca de Japón y aceptada para revisión. Los científicos trabajaron con la ciudad de Kurashiki y la bodega Funao, probando diferentes líneas hasta elegir la mejor.

**Impacto**  
Muscat Shiragai combina características especiales de la uva silvestre, como alto contenido de azúcar y resistencia a enfermedades, con el sabor suave de las uvas Muscat. Las primeras catas describieron la uva como dulce y el vino como suave con un aroma sutil a Muscat. Esta nueva uva es importante porque puede ayudar a aumentar el orgullo local, el turismo y la economía al crear un vino único de Okayama. También ayuda a proteger la rara uva silvestre Shiraga al usar su genética de una manera nueva.

**Próximo paso**  
Actualmente, 20 plantas están creciendo en la universidad y la bodega, con planes para expandirse a 300 plantas. El equipo espera cosechar más de 500 kilogramos de uvas para 2028-2029. También están mejorando las técnicas de cultivo para obtener mejores uvas. Se espera la aprobación completa de la variedad en los próximos cuatro a cinco años, después de lo cual el vino podría producirse y venderse ampliamente.

**Resumen en una frase**  
Científicos en Okayama crearon una nueva uva para vino que combina genética silvestre rara con sabores cultivados, con el objetivo de enriquecer la cultura y economía local mediante un vino único y de alta calidad.
